comments.commentBody:
MOL. can you use MOTHRA in a song? I can... think of Casablanca and "As time goes by" and the first line of this memorable melody from Dooley Wilson's lips..."You MOTHRA remember this, a kiss is just a kiss, a sigh is just"...well, I can tell it's all coming back to you now. As for RODAN, picture Yul Brynner and his guns for hire in "The Magnificent Seven" atop their stately steed's as they RODAN to town together...I'm stretching here, I'm stretching here!
Jane C, Neither the wifey nor I ever tackle Sunday's XW, however, I personally read the blog and scan through the comments, just as I did tonight to see yours @ #2 that made mention of my initials.
Have a pleasant Sabbath you two, and to rest of our WP friends, the same.

Deb, you wrote: The other theme entry I liked a lot was A WINK AND A PRAYER (“Singles bar pickup strategy?”) Is that what those men are doing? I just assumed it was a tic.

What about those women?

I was sitting even with the six-yard box on Spain's attacking end in the first half. As noted, it was a number of the starters from the Euro/World/Champions League winners vs. the US B (or C) team. 3-0 in the first half, and it wasn't that close. There were actually 4 goals in the first half (the offside call was wrong) and there should have been more (at least 2 and probably 3). Even Torres eventually scored a goal, something that only West Ham allowed during his time at Chelsea this EPL term.

@5 - how much confidence do you get from a 4-0 beatdown? which was really 5-0 as the offsides call was wrong, and which probably should have been more like 6-0 or 7-0

I disagree with the premise (like @10) but for a different reason. If we want football to catch on in America, Team USA is going to have to play and beat the best teams in the world. Rightly or wrongly, the US public only likes a winner and will only pay attention to big games and big results. There was much more attention placed on this game than there will be on the Gold Cup games. This was a big opportunity, and not only was it wasted, it was a step backwards.

Chandler should remember Giuseppe Rossi's possible miscalcuation. Rossi Chose Italy instead of playing for the United States. Rossi, was not taken by Italy to the World Cup. That was costly. He may still prevail in 2014, however, his competition will be fierce, his spot not guaranteed.

Had he chosen to play for the United States he most likely would have become the focal point of the team and US Soccer's "golden boy", even eclipsing Landon Donovan. In choosing the United States Rossi would be, a big fish in a small pond connected to the ocean. Meaning, though soccer is still in its infancy in the United States, it is still the biggest sports market in the world, he would have received greater attention here (as opposed to Europe), that he is not presently receiving in the form of endorsements. Think not; look at the top flight sponsors of the United States Federation. Not everything is about money? A soccer player's career is finite; they must earn all they can before their window of opportunity closes. Chandler knows this well and understands International competition make his value to a prospective club more desirable.

Bob Bradley is savvy. He played his hand well in becoming coach, acting as interim coach, and then becoming coach when Jurgen Klingsman declined. He will not let Chandler go without a fight. Chandler’s talents were cleary demonstrated (Argentina and Paraguay exhibitions) and his skills more in demand for the USSF, as opposed to Germany.

Jermaine Jones understood this well, and chose the United States, as he knew his chances of playing in World Cup for the United States are far better than for Germany, which chose not to take him to Full Men's National team.

Chandler should and most likely hitch his wagon to the USSF Star.

Israel has a national team comprised solely of Israeli nationals, and will be hosting the Qualifiers for the European Championship this coming July.  Rounding out that team with some MLBers could certainly make them a threat in the upcoming WBC.  Thats why they were chosen.....

That's a joke, right? That you're comparing the NBC/NHL ratings favorably to the ratings for the Man U - Barcelona Champions League final on Fox Soccer Channel and the Spanish networks. Is that supposed to be an impressive triumph for the NHL?

@Derek - so wrong at so many levels  it's hard to know where to start.  1) Bettman is "humbled" and Atlanta is an "indictment" of a "reckless" strategy?  Grow up.  Seriously.  The success or failure of a franchise is dependent on so many factors.  What didn't work for the North Stars has been changed for the Wild (an old arena in Bloomington vs a new one in St. Paul, for example.)   Even hockey-mad Canada has almost lost the Flames, the Oilers, and the Senators in recent years. It was Bettman that created the Canadian Assistance Plan that kept Canadian teams afloat.  Caps owner Ted Leonsis recalled, ‘I remember having to pay corporate welfare to help Canadian clubs in the N.H.L. under the banner of an assistance program. I remember a broker coming to me to sell the Montreal Canadiens on the cheap. The book was being sent around via e-mail to buy the team and an American bought it for a song. That was not long ago.’  2) Bettman has said on many occasions that moving a franchise was a "last resort"; if a deal can be struck to keep the Phoenix franchise from moving, that's consistent with his previous statements. Calling it "desperation" just makes you sound bitter.  3) to say that Winnipeggers got back a team "they should arguably have never lost in the first place" is just plain ignorant.  There was no one willing to buy the team _and_ keep the team in Winnipeg.  There was no salary cap to fix player costs, which were spiraling upward.  The Canadian dollar was worth about 65 cents in the US.  Player contracts often insisted on payment in US Dollars.  But...times have changed.  I'm very happy for Winnipeg (and curious what the name of the team will be.)  And I agree -- "Bettman will never be a revered character in Canada" but it's mostly because of Canadians who give him too much blame when things go wrong, and no credit for all the things that he's done right in support of Canadian teams.  But that's not the politically correct stance in the True North, so continue trolling.  Haters gotta hate.

This is the first ban on a Jewish religious practice that has reached the ballot box in the US. I hope it fails. I am very offended and somewhat threatened.
I am a secular Jew. I am circumcised as are my sons. None of us have any sexual dysfunction and those who claim to have it because of circumcision are probably neurotic for other reasons.
When my grandson was circumcised by a mohel-doctor, it was done with a local. He winced from the local but was oblivious to the cut. He required no dressing after three days.
If the San Francisco ban passes, I will boycott the city as best I can and provide whatever support I can for those who violate the law. I will further consider opposing anything that is supported by those who want to take away my religious freedom.

//"the requirement of Jewish law dates back to Abraham’s circumcision of himself."\\

Therefore, all religious circumcisions should be self-circumcisions.

All other circumcisions should be considered child abuse and illegal.
From the state that practically invented and mandated breast augmentation, teeth whitening and liposuction comes this little news gem.

the fact that these people use a cute little pun to label themselves(intactivists) illustrates how this movement is nothing more than a silly pet project for people with nothing better to do with their time.

Activists states:

“This is a conversation we are long overdue to have in this country,” he said. “The end goal for us is making cutting boys’ foreskin a federal crime.”

Freedom is about protection from this Blizzard of private restrictions. If you don't want your child circumcised, then don't do it. For the rest of us, who's culture considers it essential, then our choice is also valid.

We don't have to contend with just the nanny state, but now the nanny neighbor.A blizzard of local, state and federal legislation bounding every nook and cranny of our lives, and we kepp talking about freedom... that's a joke right!.

I know it sounds like the wrong time to be worrying about this. But I have to say that, like all regious mandates, circuncision is pretty silly. Just think about the argument that god wants it done... If that were the case, we would be born without it! If you think about it, a lot of these religious mandates (wash your feet before entering the mosque, do not eat pork, do not eat cows, get a circuncision, always wear a hat, etc.) made a lot of sense when they were instituted: these were times with poor sanitary conditions, when people were not educated about health risks, etc. It was great "public health policy"! But, in today's societies, they make little sense. Why not let the kids grow up and decide for themselves? Why does this have to be done on babies? I have to say that I agree with this ban. And I feel blessed that no religion has mandated that we should all get nose piercings...

I find the issue of consent to be very compelling. What makes it interesting is that we have made exceptions to consent laws for many other reproductive health issues, allowing the wishes of a minor to trump that of their parents.

A twelve year old girl, for example, cannot consent to a tonsillectomy on her own (parental consent is required), but she is allowed to consent to birth control pills, prenatal care, and STI treatment (in most, almost all, and all states, respectively) without her parents' input. In other words, we have already altered our laws to respect the autonomy of young patients when it comes to their reproductive health, because it is such a private matter.

If reproductive autonomy is so important as to be granted an exception in minor consent laws, why doesn't circumcision fall under this umbrella? Why is it that it is still the parents' wishes that get to determine if a male will have a permanent genital alteration, when all other consent laws are leaning the other way?

As someone who truly was genitally mutilated through Routine (but totally unnecessary) Infant Circumcision, I applaud the efforts in San Francisco and Santa Monica.

Boys deserve equal rights when it comes to genital integrity. Teenagers and men deserve the right to have fulfilling sex lives, free of pain and suffering.

I'm appalled that so many people have so little respect for such a basic human right.

I think this campaign against circumcision is a kind of hypocrisy of people who don't know what do with themselves. I wonder why don't they campaign to support the poor people of California? Or to support the libraries and schools who suffered drastic cuts in the last two years? Instead they busy themselves with a harmless operation that has been practiced for decades with no harm. Ah, and BTW Jesus himself was circumcised!

#100
I looked up your link to the SFGate of San Franciso, and you're right, what is there is unambiguously anti-Semetic and horrific. Looks like Nazi propaganda.

a civilized society must protect the defenseless from abuse. nothing less is acceptable. people can make their own decisions about their own bodies when they are old enough. no one else can make that decision for them.

surgical procedures that are not medically necessary cannot be forced on those who cannot defend themselves. society has an obligation to protect powerless infants--if we don't rise to that obligation then we are barbarians.

It is suggested that circumcision reduces male sexual pleasure. Maybe, but  I've never felt any lack of stimulation. On the other hand it's suggested that delaying male orgasm increases a woman's pleasure. In any case it hardly seems a matter for legislation.

Circumcision of infants should be discouraged, that parents are allowed to make a permanent non medically necessary change to the body of their child is abhorrent. Why not allow our children to make this decision for themselves when they are a little older, can have a say?

Despite my opposition to infant circumcision I am against these laws as proposed because they are poorly written. The San Francisco proposal specifies that one must be 18 or older to be circumcised, which I believe is too strict, and language is very broad, may have unintended consequence of interfering with consenting interventions for intersex and transgender youth.

Agree with the medical people who have commented against this barbaric procedure.
Somone who trivialised the mutilation of small boys by comparing it to femal genital mutilation missed the point. yes, female genital mutilation is terrible, but so is doing this to small boys. If men, and women for that matter, at legal age of say 18 want to mutilate their bodies, great, go for it, cut and snip as much as you like. But the law shoul dprotect children from mutilation. Always.
To those who recommend genital mutilation of little boys for hygenic reasons, I say, what do you do with your nose, snot tends to collect in there - Chop it off, and also wax forms in our ears, should they also be chopped off.
parents should teach their kids how to wash themsleves. Doesn't that make more sense.

Jena, you have my vote
It seems like Californians may have a few other more pressing issues like balancing their budget, higher education, and border issues that warrant more attention.

This movement smacks of antisemitism and I don't like it. That being said, medical research on groups of circumcised Jewish couples led to the discovery of the cause of cervical cancer, and to the validation of this practice, which is of Biblical origin. God is laughing at these people.

Circumcisions have been performed safely probably over a billion times over many thousands of years, is routine practice in the Unites States and the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention publishes evidence of medical benefits, which include protection against urinary tract infections and sexually transmitted diseases. And the American Academy of Pediatrics acknowledges the health advantages.

The procedure is usually performed in newborns days after birth using local anesthesia -- a numbing cream or an injection into the skin and requires no sutures. Complications are rare and easily treated.

But circumcision of older children and adults requires general anesthesia, sutures, comprehensive after care and has all the dangers involving surgery, both physical and psychological.
